source.title: Effective connectivity reveals important roles for both the hyperdirect (fronto-subthalamic) and the indirect (fronto-striatal-pallidal) fronto-basal ganglia pathways during response inhibition

confidence_rationale: Effective connectivity evidence directly supports multi-path inhibitory control during response suppression.

mapping.source_claim_statement: Both hyperdirect and indirect fronto-basal ganglia routes contribute to stopping behavior.
mapping.ree_translation: Supports MECH-026 by suggesting vigilance restraint uses coordinated inhibitory pathways rather than a single stop channel.
mapping.mapping_caveat: Task-specific stopping paradigms may underrepresent broader ecological vigilance states.
mapping.source_context: Human response inhibition with model-based effective connectivity.

confidence_components.notes: Strong circuit mapping support for multi-lane restraint control.
